  <!-- Main Content -->
  <section class="pt-24 pb-12 bg-gradient-to-br from-emerald-50 to-teal-50">
    <div class="max-w-4xl mx-auto px-6 text-center">
      <h1 class="text-5xl md:text-6xl font-playfair font-bold text-emerald-900 mb-6">
        Reflections & Essays
      </h1>
      <p class="text-xl md:text-2xl text-emerald-700 mb-8 max-w-2xl mx-auto">
        A critical reflection on our design journey, challenges faced, and lessons learned.
      </p>
    </div>
  </section>

  <!-- Reflections Categories -->
  <section class="py-16 bg-white">
    <div class="max-w-6xl mx-auto px-6">
      <!-- Category Navigation -->
      <div class="flex flex-wrap justify-center mb-12 space-x-0 space-y-2 md:space-y-0 md:space-x-4">
        <button class="reflection-tab active px-6 py-3 rounded-full font-medium transition-all duration-300"
          data-category="individual">
          Individual Reflections
        </button>
        <button class="reflection-tab px-6 py-3 rounded-full font-medium transition-all duration-300"
          data-category="team">
          Team Reflections
        </button>
        <button class="reflection-tab px-6 py-3 rounded-full font-medium transition-all duration-300"
          data-category="event">
          Event Reflections
        </button>
      </div>

      <!-- Individual Reflections -->
      <div id="individual" class="reflection-content active">
        <div class="space-y-8">
          <div
            class="reflection-card bg-gradient-to-br from-blue-50 to-indigo-50 p-8 rounded-2xl shadow-lg hover:shadow-xl transition-all duration-300">
            <div class="flex items-center mb-4">
              <div
                class="w-12 h-12 bg-blue-500 rounded-full flex items-center justify-center text-white font-bold text-lg mr-4">
                üí≠
              </div>
              <h3 class="text-2xl font-playfair font-bold text-gray-800">Lew Jiajun </h3>
            </div>
            <div class="reflection-content-wrapper">
              <p class="text-gray-700 leading-relaxed mb-6">
                Going through this eventful journey from requirement gathering to solution designing has taught me
                various lessons and enhanced my views and modus operandi. It has taught me insightful lessons such as:
                how to ask good questions through the ‚Äúmum test‚Äù, handling conflicts during ideation by integrating
                them, how everybody has different mental models and the risks, benefits and how‚Äôs of aligning our mental
                models, the importance of integrating user feedback into our design process and many more lessons among
                those.
              </p>
              <div class="expanded-content" style="display: none;">
                <p class="text-gray-700 leading-relaxed mb-4">
                  One memorable learning experience was when I was heavily involved with the ideation and prototyping
                  process of this project. After finishing my segment, I simply handed over to the person in charge of
                  the next step of the project and took my hands off of it. However, due to my negligence, the intended
                  solution started diverging from the intended solution.
                </p>
                <p class="text-gray-700 leading-relaxed mb-4">
                  To remedy this, the team realigned our views of the solution by consolidating our diverging views onto
                  a thinking model for a shared mental model throughout the team. This experience taught me the valuable
                  lesson of keeping my involvement to ensure that my team members are on the same page and pursue a
                  unified solution. The stages involved in designing a solution should not be silo but a constant
                  collaborative journey.
                </p>
                <p class="text-gray-700 leading-relaxed mb-4">
                  This project has taught me numerous valuable lessons that will stick with me and shape how I approach
                  future collaborative work. I‚Äôve learnt that good design isn‚Äôt just about having strong individual
                  ideas but also co-creating with others, aligning perspectives, and continuously validating assumptions
                  with real users. Moving forward, I‚Äôll be more intentional about maintaining open communication across
                  stages, staying engaged beyond my assigned tasks, and embracing tension and feedback as opportunities
                  for growth. These takeaways have not only enhanced my design thinking skills but also made me a more
                  reflective and adaptive team member.
                </p>
              </div>
              <button
                class="read-more-btn mt-4 text-blue-600 hover:text-blue-800 font-medium transition-colors duration-200 flex items-center">
                <span class="btn-text">Read More</span>
                <svg class="w-4 h-4 ml-2 transition-transform duration-200 btn-icon" fill="none" stroke="currentColor"
                  viewBox="0 0 24 24">
                  <path stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round" stroke-width="2" d="M19 9l-7 7-7-7"></path>
                </svg>
              </button>
            </div>
          </div>

          <div
            class="reflection-card bg-gradient-to-br from-green-50 to-emerald-50 p-8 rounded-2xl shadow-lg hover:shadow-xl transition-all duration-300">
            <div class="flex items-center mb-4">
              <div
                class="w-12 h-12 bg-green-500 rounded-full flex items-center justify-center text-white font-bold text-lg mr-4">
                üí°
              </div>
              <h3 class="text-2xl font-playfair font-bold text-gray-800">Deston Seet</h3>
            </div>
            <div class="reflection-content-wrapper">
              <p class="text-gray-700 leading-relaxed mb-6">
                Over the course of this project, I had the opportunity to work on every aspects of the project, from the
                ideation phase all the way to the final documentation of the proposed solution. I would say the journey
                had been interesting and fulfilling with many ups and downs.
              </p>
              <div class="expanded-content" style="display: none;">
                <p class="text-gray-700 leading-relaxed mb-4">
                  The journey started at the ideation and problem statement clarification. At that stage, we were trying
                  to figure out the details of the problem, gain context knowledge as well as brainstorm some potential
                  ideas and solutions. This ideation phase was filled with back and forth conversation, clarifying each
                  other‚Äôs understanding of the problem as well as the objective that we are specifically trying to
                  solve. Throwing ideas around helped us find the best features that will solve the pain points of the
                  problem. Looking back, I personally think that the mood of the discussion was the most important
                  aspect. The right mood among my team members allowed everyone to contribute their thoughts and ideas
                  freely without repercussions or judgments. The final solution was a combination of everyone‚Äôs inputs
                  and apprehension, which fully satisfy the objective we laid out at the start of the ideation process.
                  Therefore, I am glad that we, as a group, jelled well together and maintained a professional yet
                  friendly atmosphere within the group, striving to reach the best idea possible.
                </p>
                <p class="text-gray-700 leading-relaxed mb-4">
                  The next major phase is the prototyping phase, which involves iterating through the prototype as it
                  goes from lo-fi, mid-fi and high-fi. As it iterates, the word journey fits it really well. The process
                  feels like a journey where it progressively builds on the past work, taking in different kind of
                  feedback along the way in order to become a final prototype that reflects the final product. My
                  takeaway is exactly that it was more of a journey than anything else and should be seen as 1 whole
                  process. One of the key event during this process was that we tried to hasten the process by doing the
                  mid-fi and high-fi simultaneously, skipping user feedback and proceeding with what we think was right.
                  This came to haunt us as we realised that we missed many issues that could have been identified during
                  the mid-fi stage. We learnt that there are no shortcut on the road to quality. I used to see
                  prototyping as 3 different phases but after this experience, I see them as a long process that build
                  ontop of each other to reach a quality product at the end.
                </p>
                <p class="text-gray-700 leading-relaxed mb-4">
                  While this project is coming to an end, the takeaways will stay with me in my future works and it had
                  been an pleasant experience doing this project in Glasgow.
                </p>
              </div>
              <button
                class="read-more-btn mt-4 text-green-600 hover:text-green-800 font-medium transition-colors duration-200 flex items-center">
                <span class="btn-text">Read More</span>
                <svg class="w-4 h-4 ml-2 transition-transform duration-200 btn-icon" fill="none" stroke="currentColor"
                  viewBox="0 0 24 24">
                  <path stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round" stroke-width="2" d="M19 9l-7 7-7-7"></path>
                </svg>
              </button>
            </div>
          </div>
          <div
            class="reflection-card bg-gradient-to-br from-purple-50 to-violet-50 p-8 rounded-2xl shadow-lg hover:shadow-xl transition-all duration-300">
            <div class="flex items-center mb-4">
              <div
                class="w-12 h-12 bg-purple-500 rounded-full flex items-center justify-center text-white font-bold text-lg mr-4">
                üå∏
              </div>
              <h3 class="text-2xl font-playfair font-bold text-gray-800">Ma Wen Xi</h3>
            </div>
            <div class="reflection-content-wrapper">
              <p class="text-gray-700 leading-relaxed mb-6">

              </p>
              <div class="expanded-content" style="display: none;">
                <p class="text-gray-700 leading-relaxed mb-4">

                </p>
                <p class="text-gray-700 leading-relaxed mb-4">

                </p>
                <p class="text-gray-700 leading-relaxed mb-4">

                </p>
              </div>
              <button
                class="read-more-btn mt-4 text-purple-600 hover:text-purple-800 font-medium transition-colors duration-200 flex items-center">
                <span class="btn-text">Read More</span>
                <svg class="w-4 h-4 ml-2 transition-transform duration-200 btn-icon" fill="none" stroke="currentColor"
                  viewBox="0 0 24 24">
                  <path stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round" stroke-width="2" d="M19 9l-7 7-7-7"></path>
                </svg>
              </button>
            </div>
          </div>
          <div
            class="reflection-card bg-gradient-to-br from-pink-50 to-rose-50 p-8 rounded-2xl shadow-lg hover:shadow-xl transition-all duration-300">
            <div class="flex items-center mb-4">
              <div
                class="w-12 h-12 bg-pink-500 rounded-full flex items-center justify-center text-white font-bold text-lg mr-4">
                üé®
              </div>
              <h3 class="text-2xl font-playfair font-bold text-gray-800">Hannah Woo</h3>
            </div>
            <div class="reflection-content-wrapper">
              <p class="text-gray-700 leading-relaxed mb-6">
                Working on the Figma prototype for the species identification website was a valuable exercise in both
                design precision and empathy. I had to pay close attention to detail,not just in terms of layout,
                colors, and consistency, but also in how the interface would actually be used by real experts in the
                field. The experts had an important task on verifying several species types in sometimes subtle visual
                differences in photos, so it was crucial to provide a seamless and smooth experience.
              </p>
              <div class="expanded-content" style="display: none;">
                <p class="text-gray-700 leading-relaxed mb-4">
                  Designing for that kind of workflow meant stepping into their shoes and imagining what would make
                  their job easier and more efficient. I had to think about how images are displayed, how information is
                  prioritized, and how easy it is to compare, tag, or reject submissions. The goal was to reduce
                  cognitive load and friction in the process, without sacrificing clarity or scientific accuracy. It
                  challenged me to design not just something that looked good, but something that supports critical,
                  detail-oriented work.
                </p>
              </div>
              <button
                class="read-more-btn mt-4 text-pink-600 hover:text-pink-800 font-medium transition-colors duration-200 flex items-center">
                <span class="btn-text">Read More</span>
                <svg class="w-4 h-4 ml-2 transition-transform duration-200 btn-icon" fill="none" stroke="currentColor"
                  viewBox="0 0 24 24">
                  <path stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round" stroke-width="2" d="M19 9l-7 7-7-7"></path>
                </svg>
              </button>
            </div>
          </div>
          <div
            class="reflection-card bg-gradient-to-br from-amber-50 to-yellow-50 p-8 rounded-2xl shadow-lg hover:shadow-xl transition-all duration-300">
            <div class="flex items-center mb-4">
              <div
                class="w-12 h-12 bg-amber-500 rounded-full flex items-center justify-center text-white font-bold text-lg mr-4">
                ‚≠ê
              </div>
              <h3 class="text-2xl font-playfair font-bold text-gray-800">Jolie Yeo</h3>
            </div>
            <div class="reflection-content-wrapper">
              <p class="text-gray-700 leading-relaxed mb-6">
                Designing the Figma prototype for the species identification website pushed me to think deeply about
                creating a visually appealing, seamless, and intuitive user experience. Throughout the design process, I
                found myself constantly evaluating decisions against Nielsen's usability heuristics, particularly
                focusing on how each choice would impact the mental workload of researchers engaged in
                detailed-oriented, repetitive identification tasks.
              </p>
              <div class="expanded-content" style="display: none;">
                <p class="text-gray-700 leading-relaxed mb-4">
                  I became increasingly aware of how much small, thoughtful choices matter. For example, emphasis on
                  consistency in spacing, type hierarchy, and color usage to ensure a clean visual rhythm. Rather than
                  drawing attention to the design itself, I aimed to let the content and the task at hand stay front and
                  center. It was a balance of form and function, where aesthetics serve usability. Seeing the pieces
                  slowly but surely come together in a way that feels natural and smooth was definitely one of the most
                  satisfying parts of the process.
                </p>
                <p class="text-gray-700 leading-relaxed mb-4">
                  Moreover, another complex challenge I faced was designing for such a varied group of users, not just
                  because of their varying levels of expertise, but because each group accessed the system through
                  different entry points and needed different functionalities. This pushed me to think very critically
                  about user journeys. This meant that I had to put myself in the various users‚Äô shoes and gain insights
                  on their expectations as well as their pain points, which the interviews and discussions conducted
                  helped tremendously. It definitely was a little frustrating having to go through countless iterations
                  to align with what the entire team wanted but the innate passion to solve the problem deeply motivated
                  me. I wanted to create tailored and curated experiences that also felt cohesive across the entire
                  platform. I tried to maintain consistency in core design elements, while also allowing flexibility in
                  layout and functionality depending on who was accessing the page. This experience gave me a much
                  clearer appreciation of the ‚Äúflexibility and efficiency of use‚Äù heuristic, and how it can be
                  implemented through adaptive design.
                </p>
              </div>
              <button
                class="read-more-btn mt-4 text-amber-600 hover:text-amber-800 font-medium transition-colors duration-200 flex items-center">
                <span class="btn-text">Read More</span>
                <svg class="w-4 h-4 ml-2 transition-transform duration-200 btn-icon" fill="none" stroke="currentColor"
                  viewBox="0 0 24 24">
                  <path stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round" stroke-width="2" d="M19 9l-7 7-7-7"></path>
                </svg>
              </button>
            </div>
          </div>
          <div
            class="reflection-card bg-gradient-to-br from-indigo-50 to-purple-50 p-8 rounded-2xl shadow-lg hover:shadow-xl transition-all duration-300">
            <div class="flex items-center mb-4">
              <div
                class="w-12 h-12 bg-indigo-500 rounded-full flex items-center justify-center text-white font-bold text-lg mr-4">
                ÔøΩ
              </div>
              <h3 class="text-2xl font-playfair font-bold text-gray-800">Isaiah Ang</h3>
            </div>
            <div class="reflection-content-wrapper">
              <p class="text-gray-700 leading-relaxed mb-6">

              </p>
              <div class="expanded-content" style="display: none;">
                <p class="text-gray-700 leading-relaxed mb-4">

                </p>
                <p class="text-gray-700 leading-relaxed mb-4">

                </p>
              </div>
              <button
                class="read-more-btn mt-4 text-indigo-600 hover:text-indigo-800 font-medium transition-colors duration-200 flex items-center">
                <span class="btn-text">Read More</span>
                <svg class="w-4 h-4 ml-2 transition-transform duration-200 btn-icon" fill="none" stroke="currentColor"
                  viewBox="0 0 24 24">
                  <path stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round" stroke-width="2" d="M19 9l-7 7-7-7"></path>
                </svg>
              </button>
            </div>
          </div>
        </div>
      </div>

      <!-- Team Reflections -->
      <div id="team" class="reflection-content">
        <div class="bg-gradient-to-r from-emerald-50 to-teal-50 p-6 rounded-xl mb-8 border-l-4 border-emerald-500">
          <p class="text-lg text-gray-700 leading-relaxed">
            Over the past three weeks, our team collaborated on a project aimed at streamlining the current process of
            species identification. Reflecting on the work we produced, we are proud of what we have managed to achieve
            within this short time frame. However, there are also many areas where we could have performed better as a
            team. Overall, the experience was deeply insightful and helped us to understand how we could work better as
            a team in future projects.
          </p>
        </div>
        <div class="space-y-8">
          <div
            class="reflection-card bg-gradient-to-br from-orange-50 to-red-50 p-8 rounded-2xl shadow-lg hover:shadow-xl transition-all duration-300">
            <div class="flex items-center mb-4">
              <div
                class="w-12 h-12 bg-orange-500 rounded-full flex items-center justify-center text-white font-bold text-lg mr-4">
                ü§ù
              </div>
              <h3 class="text-2xl font-playfair font-bold text-gray-800">What we are proud of</h3>
            </div>
            <div class="reflection-content-wrapper">
              <p class="text-gray-700 leading-relaxed mb-6">
                One strength we recognised was our team‚Äôs willingness to adapt, especially when we didn‚Äôt initially
                agree on a particular approach. Whilst the team was in the process of creating the prototype, we had
                differing views on the layout of the page where the expert would verify the identification of the
                species.
              </p>
              <div class="expanded-content" style="display: none;">
                <p class="text-gray-700 leading-relaxed mb-4">
                  Initially, our layout did not account for the expert to ‚Äúdisagree‚Äù with the prediction of the model.
                  One of our team members pointed out this concern, leading on a discussion on whether or not to include
                  a separate disagree button for the AI model prediction, and the justification for each. While
                  maintaining a single button would be simpler, and the disagree button would rely on the iNaturalist‚Äôs
                  identification and train the model in the background, having a separate button would allow the expert
                  to provide direct feedback to our model.
                </p>
                <p class="text-gray-700 leading-relaxed mb-4">
                  We opted to have separate disagree buttons for the model and
                  iNaturalist, as it improved the clarity and functionality of the expert input process. As such, with
                  this, even though we had disagreements, we weighed different perspectives and decided on the option
                  that gave the most value.
                </p>
              </div>
              <button
                class="read-more-btn mt-4 text-orange-600 hover:text-orange-800 font-medium transition-colors duration-200 flex items-center">
                <span class="btn-text">Read More</span>
                <svg class="w-4 h-4 ml-2 transition-transform duration-200 btn-icon" fill="none" stroke="currentColor"
                  viewBox="0 0 24 24">
                  <path stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round" stroke-width="2" d="M19 9l-7 7-7-7"></path>
                </svg>
              </button>
            </div>
          </div>

          <div
            class="reflection-card bg-gradient-to-br from-teal-50 to-cyan-50 p-8 rounded-2xl shadow-lg hover:shadow-xl transition-all duration-300">
            <div class="flex items-center mb-4">
              <div
                class="w-12 h-12 bg-teal-500 rounded-full flex items-center justify-center text-white font-bold text-lg mr-4">
                ‚ö°
              </div>
              <h3 class="text-2xl font-playfair font-bold text-gray-800">What we are not proud of</h3>
            </div>
            <div class="reflection-content-wrapper">
              <p class="text-gray-700 leading-relaxed mb-6">
                While there were many things we were proud of, we regretted not properly testing some of our initial
                ideas before implementing them. This led to design decisions that had to be reworked, affecting both our
                timeline and confidence in the solution.
              </p>
              <div class="expanded-content" style="display: none;">
                <p class="text-gray-700 leading-relaxed mb-4">
                  During the early prototyping stages, we lacked user and team feedback. After completing our
                  low-fidelity (Lo-Fi) prototype, we did not gather any feedback for our design, and moved straight into
                  developing the mid-fidelity (Mid-Fi) prototype. The same problem continued with the Mid-Fi prototype,
                  with us not consulting users or prompting any discussion within our team on any potential
                  improvements.
                </p>
                <p class="text-gray-700 leading-relaxed mb-4">
                  When we developed the high-fidelity (Hi-Fi), then only did we seek user feedback. The feedback given
                  revealed many core design issues that had not been addressed. This led to multiple iterations of the
                  prototype, which led to a series of delays and difficult changes due to the time-consuming and complex
                  nature of Hi-Fi prototype revision. This could have been avoided had we sought user feedback in all
                  steps of the prototyping stages.
                </p>
                <p class="text-gray-700 leading-relaxed mb-4">
                  This experience taught us the importance of user testing and feedback at every stage of the design
                  process. In future projects, we will prioritise this early, ensuring that user feedback is gotten in
                  the early stages to ensure that the prototype is going in the right direction.
                </p>
              </div>
              <button
                class="read-more-btn mt-4 text-teal-600 hover:text-teal-800 font-medium transition-colors duration-200 flex items-center">
                <span class="btn-text">Read More</span>
                <svg class="w-4 h-4 ml-2 transition-transform duration-200 btn-icon" fill="none" stroke="currentColor"
                  viewBox="0 0 24 24">
                  <path stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round" stroke-width="2" d="M19 9l-7 7-7-7"></path>
                </svg>
              </button>
            </div>
          </div>
        </div>

        <div class="bg-gradient-to-r from-blue-50 to-indigo-50 p-6 rounded-xl mt-8 border-l-4 border-blue-500">
          <h3 class="text-xl font-playfair font-bold text-gray-800 mb-4">Conclusion</h3>
          <p class="text-lg text-gray-700 leading-relaxed">
            In conclusion, despite the obstacles that we faced throughout the project, the experiences gained was a
            valuable opportunity for growth both individually and as a team. We learnt the importance of early and
            consistent feedback, and the need to be adaptable when changes arise. We enjoyed the process doing this
            project, and value the insights gained.
          </p>
        </div>
      </div>

      <!-- Event Reflections -->
      <div id="event" class="reflection-content">
        <!-- <div class="grid md:grid-cols-2 gap-8 mb-12"> -->
        <div
          class="reflection-card bg-gradient-to-br from-rose-50 to-pink-50 p-8 rounded-2xl shadow-lg hover:shadow-xl transition-all duration-300 mb-8">
          <div class="flex items-center mb-4">
            <div
              class="w-12 h-12 bg-rose-500 rounded-full flex items-center justify-center text-white font-bold text-lg mr-4">
              üî¨
            </div>
            <h3 class="text-2xl font-playfair font-bold text-gray-800">Asking better questions with a Shared mental
              model using AEIOU
            </h3>
          </div>
          <div class="reflection-content-wrapper">
            <p class="text-gray-700 leading-relaxed mb-6">
              Our team's project started with a critical misalignment in our understanding of the problem. We each
              interpreted the problem statement differently, leading to confusion and a lack of clear direction. From
              this, we learnt that a shared understanding isn't guaranteed and is instead a deliberate, active, and
              explicit process.
            </p>
            <div class="expanded-content" style="display: none;">
              <p class="text-gray-700 leading-relaxed mb-4">
                The initial disconnect came from the use of iNaturalist within our solution. Team members were not
                sure if our partner needed an app like iNaturalist or to integrate iNaturalist into the solution. This
                was one of many confusions about the premise of the problem. Due to the open-ended nature of the
                problem statement that lacked specific constraints, there were a broad range of interpretations about
                the premise and context of the problem. There were many questions that we wanted to ask, but we were
                unsure if our questions were able to target all the different user needs and perspectives. We learnt
                that when tackling an open-ended problem, there are too many viewpoints to take into consideration and
                we needed a way to consolidate them.

              </p>
              <p class="text-gray-700 leading-relaxed mb-4">
                To fix this, we used the AEIOU method to systematically map out our thoughts and created a shared
                mental model. It allowed us to consider things from the point of view of: activities, environment
                interactions, objects and users, which gave us a comprehensive overview of gaps in our questions. This
                allowed the questions we crafted to have a more holistic view to uncover various users and their
                needs. We learnt the importance of having a shared mental model within our group to align our goals
                and the importance of charting the different viewpoints involved with the problem.

              </p>
              <p class="text-gray-700 leading-relaxed mb-4">
                One particularly memorable session involved shadowing an expert botanist during their routine survey
                work.
                Observing their workflow, noting patterns, and understanding the cognitive load involved in species
                identification completely reshaped our approach to interface design. We realized our initial designs
                were far too complex for field use.
              </p>
              <p class="text-gray-700 leading-relaxed mb-4">
                The interviews also revealed the emotional aspects of citizen science participation. Users weren't
                just
                interested in data collection; they wanted to feel part of a larger conservation effort. This insight
                led us to incorporate progress indicators and community engagement features that made users feel their
                contributions were meaningful and impactful.
              </p>
              <p class="text-gray-700 leading-relaxed">
                Perhaps most importantly, these sessions taught us to always question our assumptions. Every
                preconceived
                notion we had about user behavior was challenged, and often proven wrong. This experience has made me
                a
                much more humble and curious designer, always eager to learn from real users rather than rely on
                intuition.
              </p>
            </div>
            <button
              class="read-more-btn mt-4 text-rose-600 hover:text-rose-800 font-medium transition-colors duration-200 flex items-center">
              <span class="btn-text">Read More</span>
              <svg class="w-4 h-4 ml-2 transition-transform duration-200 btn-icon" fill="none" stroke="currentColor"
                viewBox="0 0 24 24">
                <path stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round" stroke-width="2" d="M19 9l-7 7-7-7"></path>
              </svg>
            </button>
          </div>
        </div>

        <div
          class="reflection-card bg-gradient-to-br from-amber-50 to-orange-50 p-8 rounded-2xl shadow-lg hover:shadow-xl transition-all duration-300 mb-8">
          <div class="flex items-center mb-4">
            <div
              class="w-12 h-12 bg-amber-500 rounded-full flex items-center justify-center text-white font-bold text-lg mr-4">
              üé®
            </div>
            <h3 class="text-2xl font-playfair font-bold text-gray-800">Resolving ideation disagreements using
              integrative thinking
            </h3>
          </div>
          <div class="reflection-content-wrapper">
            <p class="text-gray-700 leading-relaxed mb-6">
              During our ideation phase, there was a divide within our group about the use of AI to automate the
              process
              as opposed to a human expert identifier. Our partner in the project made it clear that while AI can be
              helpful, it may be unreliable and so she discourages the use of it. This brought to light two opposing
              perspectives: one advocating for AI-led identification to leverage speed and scalability, and the other
              emphasizing the importance of expert judgement to ensure accuracy and trustworthiness. This clash of
              ideas
              forced us to grapple with the limitations and strengths of both approaches, having to choose one or the
              other.

            </p>
            <div class="expanded-content" style="display: none;">
              <p class="text-gray-700 leading-relaxed mb-4">
                To move forward, we applied integrative thinking. Rather than choosing one side, we faced the tension
                of
                opposing ideas to generate a creative solution that contains elements of the opposing ideas but is
                superior to simply using one. We identified the pros of each idea and identified the central tension
                of
                ‚ÄúHow can we use both AI and human expertise without compromising reliability or efficiency?‚Äù

              </p>
              <p class="text-gray-700 leading-relaxed mb-4">
                Our breakthrough came when we proposed a system where the AI suggests a species, but the expert makes
                the final call. This approach allowed us to retain the reliability of the expert, while still
                benefiting
                from AI‚Äôs speed and consistency. By embracing the tension instead of avoiding it, we created a more
                resilient and well-rounded solution.
              </p>
              <p class="text-gray-700 leading-relaxed mb-4">
                This experience taught us several important lessons. First, conflicting ideas are not roadblocks but
                opportunities for creative resolution. Disagreements can lead to stronger, more innovative outcomes
                when
                explored thoughtfully. Second, decision-making models such as integrative thinking help push us beyond
                surface-level comparisons. They encourage deeper analysis and structured reasoning, which ultimately
                guided our team to a consensus. Lastly, we learnt that limitations like AI‚Äôs occasional inaccuracy can
                be reframed as creative constraints that drive better design. In our case, AI‚Äôs weakness of
                unreliability was mitigated when it was complemented with expert review to give the final verdict.

              </p>
              <p class="text-gray-700 leading-relaxed mb-4">
                When we encounter future opposing idea challenges, we no longer view weaknesses and constraints as
                limitations to our solution but a springboard to innovation. With integrative thinking, we can use
                structured thinking models to explore deep thinking avenues that guide us toward integrating our two
                opposing ideas into a stronger and more resilient solution.
              </p>
            </div>
            <button
              class="read-more-btn mt-4 text-amber-600 hover:text-amber-800 font-medium transition-colors duration-200 flex items-center">
              <span class="btn-text">Read More</span>
              <svg class="w-4 h-4 ml-2 transition-transform duration-200 btn-icon" fill="none" stroke="currentColor"
                viewBox="0 0 24 24">
                <path stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round" stroke-width="2" d="M19 9l-7 7-7-7"></path>
              </svg>
            </button>
          </div>
          <!-- </div> -->
        </div>

        <!-- <div class="grid md:grid-cols-2 gap-8"> -->
        <div
          class="reflection-card bg-gradient-to-br from-emerald-50 to-teal-50 p-8 rounded-2xl shadow-lg hover:shadow-xl transition-all duration-300 mb-8">
          <div class="flex items-center mb-4">
            <div
              class="w-12 h-12 bg-emerald-500 rounded-full flex items-center justify-center text-white font-bold text-lg mr-4">
              üìä
            </div>
            <h3 class="text-2xl font-playfair font-bold text-gray-800">User feedback - Testing should be done
              continuously
            </h3>
          </div>
          <div class="reflection-content-wrapper">
            <p class="text-gray-700 leading-relaxed mb-6">
              A key theme that emerged during this phase of our project was the importance of continuous user feedback
              in shaping a user-centered product. When we sought feedback on our high-fidelity prototypes, it quickly
              became apparent that our designs had various usability gaps. One screen, for example, only had a single
              ‚Äúagree‚Äù button without clearly indicating which suggestion it referred to. This ambiguity could have
              been
              easily caught earlier, had we involved users consistently throughout.
            </p>
            <div class="expanded-content" style="display: none;">
              <p class="text-gray-700 leading-relaxed mb-4">
                Reflecting on this, we recognized a major oversight in our process: we had skipped user feedback
                during
                the transition from mid-fi to high-fi, assuming that our design choices were sufficient. This
                complacency led us to rely on internal assumptions rather than real user needs. As a result, what
                seemed
                like obvious flaws in hindsight were completely missed until much later.
              </p>
              <p class="text-gray-700 leading-relaxed mb-4">
                This experience taught us that user feedback is not a one-time checkbox, but a vital and ongoing part
                of
                the design process. By neglecting it, we risked drifting away from user needs and investing time in
                refining ideas that did not fully capture the essence of our solution. In future projects, we are
                committed to embedding user testing into every stage, not just to validate our work, but to inform
                continuously. This approach will help us catch issues earlier, adapt more effectively, and stay
                aligned
                with real-world use cases.

              </p>
              <p class="text-gray-700 leading-relaxed mb-4">
                We learned to observe not just what users did, but how they felt doing it. Facial expressions, sighs
                of frustration, and moments of confusion were as valuable as click data. One participant's comment -
                "I feel stupid using this" - completely changed how we approached error messaging and help text.
                We realized that poor usability doesn't just waste time; it makes people feel bad about themselves.
              </p>
              <p class="text-gray-700 leading-relaxed mb-4">
                Ultimately, this experience deepened our understanding of user feedback in design as a collaborative
                and
                iterative process. It reminded us that the best products are not designed in isolation, but in
                conversation with the people they are meant to serve.
              </p>
            </div>
            <button
              class="read-more-btn mt-4 text-emerald-600 hover:text-emerald-800 font-medium transition-colors duration-200 flex items-center">
              <span class="btn-text">Read More</span>
              <svg class="w-4 h-4 ml-2 transition-transform duration-200 btn-icon" fill="none" stroke="currentColor"
                viewBox="0 0 24 24">
                <path stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round" stroke-width="2" d="M19 9l-7 7-7-7"></path>
              </svg>
            </button>
          </div>
        </div>

        <div
          class="reflection-card bg-gradient-to-br from-violet-50 to-purple-50 p-8 rounded-2xl shadow-lg hover:shadow-xl transition-all duration-300">
          <div class="flex items-center mb-4">
            <div
              class="w-12 h-12 bg-violet-500 rounded-full flex items-center justify-center text-white font-bold text-lg mr-4">
              üéØ
            </div>
            <h3 class="text-2xl font-playfair font-bold text-gray-800">Edge cases and disparity between developers and
              users
            </h3>
          </div>
          <div class="reflection-content-wrapper">
            <p class="text-gray-700 leading-relaxed mb-6">
              Another key learning point in our design journey emerged from continued user testing, specifically, how
              real user behaviour can challenge our initial assumptions. For the species identification feature, we
              initially designed a multi-step process: users would upload a
              photo, receive multiple AI-generated species suggestions based on confidence levels, and then select one
              to proceed to an information page. We believed that this would empower users to make more accurate
              selections and feel more in control.
            </p>
            <div class="expanded-content" style="display: none;">
              <p class="text-gray-700 leading-relaxed mb-4">
                However, user feedback revealed that this assumption was flawed. Users were not experts and in
                practice,
                most users simply selected the first option without evaluating the others, undermining the purpose of
                the feature. What we had thought was a helpful layer of precision ended up introducing friction and
                unnecessarily complicating the experience.
              </p>
              <p class="text-gray-700 leading-relaxed mb-4">
                In response, we removed the species suggestion step entirely and streamlined the user flow to lead
                directly from photo upload to the animal‚Äôs information page. This change better matched user
                expectations and behaviour, reducing confusion and making the process more efficient.

              </p>
              <p class="text-gray-700 leading-relaxed mb-4">
                This experience reinforced a critical insight: our assumptions, no matter how logical, must be
                validated
                through actual user testing. There‚Äôs often a gulf between how designers imagine a feature will be used
                and how users actually interact with it. Assumptions should not be treated as truths, but as
                hypotheses
                that need testing.

              </p>
              <p class="text-gray-700 leading-relaxed mb-4">
                User testing also helped us uncover edge cases and overlooked scenarios, particularly from the
                expert‚Äôs
                perspective. We assumed that the expert would want to log every image sourced from iNaturalist,
                believing that all data is valuable. However, feedback highlighted that some images might be of poor
                quality or irrelevant, making them unsuitable for logging. Yet, our interface had no option for the
                expert to skip or ignore such entries, an oversight on our part.

              </p>
              <p class="text-gray-700 leading-relaxed mb-4">
                This revealed the importance of designing for flexibility and real-world context, not just the ideal
                use
                case. By failing to consider exceptions, we risked frustrating users and forcing them into decisions
                that didn‚Äôt align with their goals.
              </p>
              <p class="text-gray-700 leading-relaxed">
                Overall, these experiences have taught us that user testing is not only about validation but also
                discovery. It reveals gaps, surfaces unexpected needs, and pushes us to let go of assumptions in
                favour
                of real user needs. Moving forward, we are committed to grounding our design decisions in actual user
                behaviour, not just theoretical logic, and ensuring that our solutions are shaped by the people who
                use
                them.
              </p>
            </div>
            <button
              class="read-more-btn mt-4 text-violet-600 hover:text-violet-800 font-medium transition-colors duration-200 flex items-center">
              <span class="btn-text">Read More</span>
              <svg class="w-4 h-4 ml-2 transition-transform duration-200 btn-icon" fill="none" stroke="currentColor"
                viewBox="0 0 24 24">
                <path stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round" stroke-width="2" d="M19 9l-7 7-7-7"></path>
              </svg>
            </button>
          </div>
          <!-- </div> -->
        </div>
      </div>
    </div>
  </section>

  <!-- Lessons Learned Summary -->
  <section class="py-16 bg-gradient-to-br from-emerald-50 to-teal-50">
    <div class="max-w-4xl mx-auto px-6 text-center">
      <h2 class="text-4xl font-playfair font-bold text-emerald-900 mb-8">Key Takeaways</h2>
      <div class="grid md:grid-cols-3 gap-8">
        <div class="bg-white p-6 rounded-xl shadow-lg">
          <div class="text-3xl mb-4">üå±</div>
          <h3 class="text-xl font-bold text-gray-800 mb-3">Iterative Design</h3>
          <p class="text-gray-600">Great solutions emerge through continuous refinement and user feedback, not initial
            perfection.</p>
        </div>
        <div class="bg-white p-6 rounded-xl shadow-lg">
          <div class="text-3xl mb-4">ü§ù</div>
          <h3 class="text-xl font-bold text-gray-800 mb-3">Collaboration</h3>
          <p class="text-gray-600">Diverse perspectives and open communication lead to more innovative and robust
            solutions.</p>
        </div>
        <div class="bg-white p-6 rounded-xl shadow-lg">
          <div class="text-3xl mb-4">üë•</div>
          <h3 class="text-xl font-bold text-gray-800 mb-3">User-Centered</h3>
          <p class="text-gray-600">Direct user engagement reveals insights that assumptions and secondary research
            cannot provide.</p>
        </div>
      </div>
    </div>
  </section>

  <!-- JavaScript -->
  <script src="script.js"></script>
  <script>
    // Reflection category switching
    document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', function () {
      const tabs = document.querySelectorAll('.reflection-tab');
      const contents = document.querySelectorAll('.reflection-content');

      tabs.forEach(tab => {
        tab.addEventListener('click', function () {
          const category = this.getAttribute('data-category');

          // Remove active class from all tabs and contents
          tabs.forEach(t => t.classList.remove('active'));
          contents.forEach(c => c.classList.remove('active'));

          // Add active class to clicked tab and corresponding content
          this.classList.add('active');
          document.getElementById(category).classList.add('active');
        });
      });

      // Read More functionality
      const readMoreBtns = document.querySelectorAll('.read-more-btn');

      readMoreBtns.forEach(btn => {
        btn.addEventListener('click', function () {
          const wrapper = this.closest('.reflection-content-wrapper');
          const expandedContent = wrapper.querySelector('.expanded-content');
          const btnText = this.querySelector('.btn-text');
          const btnIcon = this.querySelector('.btn-icon');

          if (expandedContent.style.display === 'none') {
            expandedContent.style.display = 'block';
            btnText.textContent = 'Read Less';
            btnIcon.style.transform = 'rotate(180deg)';

            // Smooth scroll animation
            setTimeout(() => {
              expandedContent.style.opacity = '1';
              expandedContent.style.transform = 'translateY(0)';
            }, 10);
          } else {
            expandedContent.style.opacity = '0';
            expandedContent.style.transform = 'translateY(-10px)';

            setTimeout(() => {
              expandedContent.style.display = 'none';
              btnText.textContent = 'Read More';
              btnIcon.style.transform = 'rotate(0deg)';
            }, 300);
          }
        });
      });

      // Animate cards on scroll
      const observerOptions = {
        threshold: 0.1,
        rootMargin: '0px 0px -50px 0px'
      };

      const observer = new IntersectionObserver((entries) => {
        entries.forEach(entry => {
          if (entry.isIntersecting) {
            entry.target.style.opacity = '1';
            entry.target.style.transform = 'translateY(0)';
          }
        });
      }, observerOptions);

      document.querySelectorAll('.reflection-card').forEach(card => {
        card.style.opacity = '0';
        card.style.transform = 'translateY(30px)';
        card.style.transition = 'opacity 0.6s ease, transform 0.6s ease';
        observer.observe(card);
      });
    });
  </script>
</body>

</html>

================
File: script.js
================
// JavaScript for Botaniq Project Showcase
// DOM Content Loaded Event
document.addEventListener("DOMContentLoaded", function () {
  // Initialize all functionality
  initNavigation();
  initScrollEffects();
  initInteractiveElements();
  // Note: Image comparisons are initialized via inline script for better compatibility
  initVideoModal(); // Add video modal functionality
});

// Navigation Functionality
function initNavigation() {
  const navbar = document.getElementById("navbar");
  const mobileMenuBtn = document.getElementById("mobile-menu-btn");
  const mobileMenu = document.getElementById("mobile-menu");
  const navLinks = document.querySelectorAll(".nav-link, #mobile-menu a");

  // Mobile Menu Toggle
  mobileMenuBtn.addEventListener("click", function () {
    mobileMenu.classList.toggle("hidden");
    mobileMenuBtn.classList.toggle("active");
  });

  // Close mobile menu when clicking on links
  navLinks.forEach((link) => {
    link.addEventListener("click", function () {
      mobileMenu.classList.add("hidden");
      mobileMenuBtn.classList.remove("active");
    });
  });

  // Smooth scrolling for navigation links (only for anchor links)
  navLinks.forEach((link) => {
    link.addEventListener("click", function (e) {
      const targetId = this.getAttribute("href");
      // Only prevent default for internal anchor links
      if (targetId.startsWith("#")) {
        e.preventDefault();
        const targetSection = document.querySelector(targetId);
        if (targetSection) {
          const offsetTop = targetSection.offsetTop - 80; // Account for fixed navbar
          window.scrollTo({
            top: offsetTop,
            behavior: "smooth",
          });
        }
      }
      // For external links (like timeline.html), let the browser handle navigation normally
    });
  });

  // Navbar scroll effects
  let lastScrollTop = 0;
  window.addEventListener("scroll", function () {
    const scrollTop = window.pageYOffset || document.documentElement.scrollTop;

    // Add/remove background blur based on scroll position
    if (scrollTop > 50) {
      navbar.classList.add("bg-white/95");
      navbar.classList.remove("bg-white/90");
    } else {
      navbar.classList.add("bg-white/90");
      navbar.classList.remove("bg-white/95");
    }

    // Hide/show navbar on scroll (optional)
    if (scrollTop > lastScrollTop && scrollTop > 200) {
      // Scrolling down
      navbar.style.transform = "translateY(-100%)";
    } else {
      // Scrolling up
      navbar.style.transform = "translateY(0)";
    }

    lastScrollTop = scrollTop;

    // Update active navigation link
    updateActiveNavLink();
  });

  // Logo link functionality
  const logoLink = document.getElementById("logo-link");
  if (logoLink) {
    logoLink.addEventListener("click", function (e) {
      const currentPath = window.location.pathname;
      // Check if on homepage (index.html or root)
      if (currentPath.endsWith("/") || currentPath.endsWith("index.html")) {
        e.preventDefault();
        window.scrollTo({
          top: 0,
          behavior: "smooth",
        });
      }
      // For other pages, the default href="index.html" will work
    });
  }
}

// Update active navigation link based on scroll position
function updateActiveNavLink() {
  const sections = document.querySelectorAll("section[id]");
  const navLinks = document.querySelectorAll(".nav-link");

  let current = "";
  const scrollPosition = window.pageYOffset + 100; // Offset for navbar height

  sections.forEach((section) => {
    const sectionTop = section.offsetTop;
    const sectionHeight = section.clientHeight;

    if (
      scrollPosition >= sectionTop &&
      scrollPosition < sectionTop + sectionHeight
    ) {
      current = section.getAttribute("id");
    }
  });

  navLinks.forEach((link) => {
    link.classList.remove("active");
    if (link.getAttribute("href") === `#${current}`) {
      link.classList.add("active");
    }
  });
}

// Scroll Effects and Animations
function initScrollEffects() {
  // Register GSAP ScrollTrigger plugin
  gsap.registerPlugin(ScrollTrigger);

  // Hero section animation
  gsap.from(".hero-title", {
    duration: 1.5,
    y: 50,
    opacity: 0,
    ease: "power3.out",
  });

  gsap.from(".hero-subtitle", {
    duration: 1.5,
    y: 30,
    opacity: 0,
    delay: 0.3,
    ease: "power3.out",
  });

  gsap.from(".hero-cta", {
    duration: 1.5,
    y: 30,
    opacity: 0,
    delay: 0.6,
    ease: "power3.out",
  });

  // Section animations on scroll
  const sections = document.querySelectorAll("section:not(:first-child)");
  sections.forEach((section, index) => {
    gsap.fromTo(
      section,
      {
        opacity: 0,
        y: 60,
      },
      {
        opacity: 1,
        y: 0,
        duration: 1,
        ease: "power2.out",
        scrollTrigger: {
          trigger: section,
          start: "top 80%",
          end: "bottom 20%",
          toggleActions: "play none none reverse",
        },
      }
    );
  });

  // Stagger animations for cards
  gsap.fromTo(
    ".portfolio-category",
    {
      opacity: 0,
      y: 40,
      scale: 0.9,
    },
    {
      opacity: 1,
      y: 0,
      scale: 1,
      duration: 0.8,
      stagger: 0.2,
      ease: "power2.out",
      scrollTrigger: {
        trigger: "#portfolio",
        start: "top 70%",
        toggleActions: "play none none reverse",
      },
    }
  );

  // Team member animations
  gsap.fromTo(
    ".team-member",
    {
      opacity: 0,
      y: 30,
      scale: 0.95,
    },
    {
      opacity: 1,
      y: 0,
      scale: 1,
      duration: 0.6,
      stagger: 0.15,
      ease: "power2.out",
      scrollTrigger: {
        trigger: ".team-member",
        start: "top 80%",
        toggleActions: "play none none reverse",
      },
    }
  );

  // Prototype card animations
  gsap.fromTo(
    ".prototype-card",
    {
      opacity: 0,
      x: -30,
      rotation: -5,
    },
    {
      opacity: 1,
      x: 0,
      rotation: 0,
      duration: 0.8,
      stagger: 0.2,
      ease: "power2.out",
      scrollTrigger: {
        trigger: ".prototype-card",
        start: "top 75%",
        toggleActions: "play none none reverse",
      },
    }
  );

  // Parallax effect for hero background
  gsap.to(".hero-bg", {
    yPercent: -50,
    ease: "none",
    scrollTrigger: {
      trigger: ".hero-section",
      start: "top bottom",
      end: "bottom top",
      scrub: true,
    },
  });
}

// Interactive Elements
function initInteractiveElements() {
  // Portfolio link hover effects
  const portfolioLinks = document.querySelectorAll(".portfolio-link");
  portfolioLinks.forEach((link) => {
    link.addEventListener("mouseenter", function () {
      gsap.to(this, { duration: 0.3, x: 10, ease: "power2.out" });
    });

    link.addEventListener("mouseleave", function () {
      gsap.to(this, { duration: 0.3, x: 0, ease: "power2.out" });
    });
  });

  // Card hover animations
  const cards = document.querySelectorAll(
    ".portfolio-category, .team-member, .prototype-card"
  );
  cards.forEach((card) => {
    card.addEventListener("mouseenter", function () {
      gsap.to(this, {
        duration: 0.3,
        y: -10,
        scale: 1.02,
        boxShadow: "0 25px 50px -12px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.25)",
        ease: "power2.out",
      });
    });

    card.addEventListener("mouseleave", function () {
      gsap.to(this, {
        duration: 0.3,
        y: 0,
        scale: 1,
        boxShadow: "0 10px 15px -3px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.1)",
        ease: "power2.out",
      });
    });
  });

  // Button hover effects
  const buttons = document.querySelectorAll(".btn-primary, .bg-emerald-600");
  buttons.forEach((button) => {
    button.addEventListener("mouseenter", function () {
      gsap.to(this, {
        duration: 0.3,
        scale: 1.05,
        y: -3,
        boxShadow: "0 20px 25px -5px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.1)",
        ease: "power2.out",
      });
    });

    button.addEventListener("mouseleave", function () {
      gsap.to(this, {
        duration: 0.3,
        scale: 1,
        y: 0,
        boxShadow: "0 4px 6px -1px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.1)",
        ease: "power2.out",
      });
    });
  });

  // Floating animation for icons
  const floatingElements = document.querySelectorAll(".text-4xl");
  floatingElements.forEach((element, index) => {
    gsap.to(element, {
      y: -10,
      duration: 2 + index * 0.3,
      yoyo: true,
      repeat: -1,
      ease: "power2.inOut",
      delay: index * 0.5,
    });
  });

  // Table responsive enhancement
  const tables = document.querySelectorAll("table");
  tables.forEach((table) => {
    const cells = table.querySelectorAll("td");
    const headers = table.querySelectorAll("th");

    cells.forEach((cell, index) => {
      const headerIndex = index % headers.length;
      if (headers[headerIndex]) {
        cell.setAttribute("data-label", headers[headerIndex].textContent);
      }
    });

    table.classList.add("responsive-table");
  });

  // Lazy loading for images (if any are added later)
  const images = document.querySelectorAll("img[data-src]");
  const imageObserver = new IntersectionObserver((entries, observer) => {
    entries.forEach((entry) => {
      if (entry.isIntersecting) {
        const img = entry.target;
        img.src = img.dataset.src;
        img.classList.remove("lazy");
        imageObserver.unobserve(img);
      }
    });
  });

  images.forEach((img) => imageObserver.observe(img));
}

// Video Modal Functionality
function initVideoModal() {
  console.log('üé• initVideoModal() function called!');

  const videoButtons = document.querySelectorAll('[data-video-id]');
  const videoIframe = document.getElementById('video-iframe');
  const modalTitle = document.getElementById('modal-title');
  const videoModal = document.getElementById('video-modal');

  console.log('Video buttons found:', videoButtons.length);
  console.log('Video iframe found:', !!videoIframe);
  console.log('Modal title found:', !!modalTitle);
  console.log('Video modal found:', !!videoModal);

  // Function to load video
  function loadVideo(videoId, title) {
    console.log('Loading video:', videoId, title);

    if (modalTitle && title) {
      modalTitle.textContent = title;
    }

    if (videoIframe && videoId) {
      const youtubeUrl = `https://www.youtube.com/embed/${videoId}?autoplay=1&mute=1&rel=0&enablejsapi=1`;
      console.log('Setting iframe src to:', youtubeUrl);
      videoIframe.src = youtubeUrl;
    }
  }

  // Function to clear video
  function clearVideo() {
    console.log('Clearing video');
    if (videoIframe) {
      videoIframe.src = 'about:blank';
    }
  }

  videoButtons.forEach(button => {
    button.addEventListener('click', function (e) {
      console.log('Button clicked:', this);
      const videoId = this.getAttribute('data-video-id');
      const title = this.getAttribute('data-title');

      // Store the video data on the modal for later use
      if (videoModal) {
        videoModal.setAttribute('data-current-video', videoId);
        videoModal.setAttribute('data-current-title', title);
      }

      // Try to load immediately
      loadVideo(videoId, title);

      // Also try after a delay to ensure modal is fully opened
      setTimeout(() => {
        loadVideo(videoId, title);
      }, 200);
    });
  });

  // Listen for when modal is shown (Flowbite event)
  if (videoModal) {
    // Try multiple event types that Flowbite might use
    const events = ['shown.bs.modal', 'show.bs.modal', 'flowbite:modal:show'];
    events.forEach(eventType => {
      videoModal.addEventListener(eventType, function () {
        console.log('Modal shown event:', eventType);
        const videoId = this.getAttribute('data-current-video');
        const title = this.getAttribute('data-current-title');
        if (videoId) {
          loadVideo(videoId, title);
        }
      });
    });

    // Listen for when modal is hidden
    const hideEvents = ['hidden.bs.modal', 'hide.bs.modal', 'flowbite:modal:hide'];
    hideEvents.forEach(eventType => {
      videoModal.addEventListener(eventType, function () {
        console.log('Modal hidden event:', eventType);
        clearVideo();
      });
    });
  }

  // Clear video when modal is closed
  const closeModalButtons = document.querySelectorAll('[data-modal-hide="video-modal"]');
  closeModalButtons.forEach(button => {
    button.addEventListener('click', function () {
      console.log('Close button clicked');
      clearVideo();
    });
  });

  // Also clear video when clicking outside modal
  if (videoModal) {
    videoModal.addEventListener('click', function (e) {
      if (e.target === videoModal) {
        console.log('Modal backdrop clicked');
        clearVideo();
      }
    });
  }

  // Fallback: Use MutationObserver to detect when modal becomes visible
  if (videoModal) {
    const observer = new MutationObserver(function (mutations) {
      mutations.forEach(function (mutation) {
        if (mutation.type === 'attributes' && mutation.attributeName === 'class') {
          const target = mutation.target;
          if (!target.classList.contains('hidden') && target.id === 'video-modal') {
            console.log('Modal became visible via MutationObserver');
            const videoId = target.getAttribute('data-current-video');
            const title = target.getAttribute('data-current-title');
            if (videoId) {
              setTimeout(() => loadVideo(videoId, title), 100);
            }
          }
        }
      });
    });

    observer.observe(videoModal, { attributes: true, attributeFilter: ['class'] });
  }
}

// Utility Functions
function throttle(func, limit) {
  let inThrottle;
  return function () {
    const args = arguments;
    const context = this;
    if (!inThrottle) {
      func.apply(context, args);
      inThrottle = true;
      setTimeout(() => (inThrottle = false), limit);
    }
  };
}

function debounce(func, wait, immediate) {
  let timeout;
  return function () {
    const context = this,
      args = arguments;
    const later = function () {
      timeout = null;
      if (!immediate) func.apply(context, args);
    };
    const callNow = immediate && !timeout;
    clearTimeout(timeout);
    timeout = setTimeout(later, wait);
    if (callNow) func.apply(context, args);
  };
}

// Loading Animation
window.addEventListener("load", function () {
  const loader = document.querySelector(".loader");
  if (loader) {
    gsap.to(loader, {
      duration: 0.5,
      opacity: 0,
      onComplete: () => {
        loader.style.display = "none";
      },
    });
  }
});

// Error Handling
window.addEventListener("error", function (e) {
  console.warn("An error occurred:", e.error);
});

// Accessibility Enhancements
document.addEventListener("keydown", function (e) {
  // ESC key closes mobile menu
  if (e.key === "Escape") {
    const mobileMenu = document.getElementById("mobile-menu");
    const mobileMenuBtn = document.getElementById("mobile-menu-btn");
    if (!mobileMenu.classList.contains("hidden")) {
      mobileMenu.classList.add("hidden");
      mobileMenuBtn.classList.remove("active");
    }
  }

  // Tab navigation enhancement
  if (e.key === "Tab") {
    document.body.classList.add("keyboard-nav");
  }
});

document.addEventListener("mousedown", function () {
  document.body.classList.remove("keyboard-nav");
});

// Performance optimization: Intersection Observer for animations
const observerOptions = {
  threshold: 0.1,
  rootMargin: "0px 0px -50px 0px",
};

const animationObserver = new IntersectionObserver((entries) => {
  entries.forEach((entry) => {
    if (entry.isIntersecting) {
      entry.target.classList.add("animate-in");
    }
  });
}, observerOptions);

// Observe elements for animation
document.querySelectorAll(".animate-on-scroll").forEach((el) => {
  animationObserver.observe(el);
});

// Console welcome message
console.log(`
üåø Welcome to Botaniq - Project Showcase

`);

// Image Comparison Slider functionality is now implemented via inline script in HTML for better compatibility

// Export functions for potential external use
window.BotaniqShowcase = {
  initNavigation,
  initScrollEffects,
  initAnimations: initInteractiveElements,
  updateActiveNavLink,
  throttle,
  debounce,
};

================
File: styles.css

/* Custom CSS for Botaniq Project Showcase */

/* CSS Custom Properties - Botanical Color Palette */
:root {
  --color-emerald-50: #ecfdf5;
  --color-emerald-100: #d1fae5;
  --color-emerald-200: #a7f3d0;
  --color-emerald-300: #6ee7b7;
  --color-emerald-400: #34d399;
  --color-emerald-500: #10b981;
  --color-emerald-600: #059669;
  --color-emerald-700: #047857;
  --color-emerald-800: #065f46;
  --color-emerald-900: #064e3b;
  
  --color-teal-50: #f0fdfa;
  --color-teal-100: #ccfbf1;
  --color-teal-200: #99f6e4;
  
  --font-inter: 'Inter', sans-serif;
  --font-playfair: 'Playfair Display', serif;
  
  --shadow-soft: 0 4px 6px -1px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.1), 0 2px 4px -1px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.06);
  --shadow-medium: 0 10px 15px -3px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.1), 0 4px 6px -2px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05);
  --shadow-large: 0 25px 50px -12px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.25);
}

/* Font Declarations */
.font-inter {
  font-family: var(--font-inter);
}

.font-playfair {
  font-family: var(--font-playfair);
}

/* Smooth Scrolling */
html {
  scroll-behavior: smooth;
}

/* Custom Scrollbar */
::-webkit-scrollbar {
  width: 8px;
}

::-webkit-scrollbar-track {
  background: #f1f1f1;
}

::-webkit-scrollbar-thumb {
  background: var(--color-emerald-400);
  border-radius: 4px;
}

::-webkit-scrollbar-thumb:hover {
  background: var(--color-emerald-600);
}

/* Navigation Styles - Using Tailwind for mobile responsiveness */
.nav-link {
  position: relative;
  color: #374151;
  font-weight: 500;
  text-decoration: none;
  padding: 0.5rem 0;
  transition: color 0.3s ease;
}

.nav-link::after {
  content: '';
  position: absolute;
  bottom: 0;
  left: 0;
  width: 0;
  height: 2px;
  background-color: var(--color-emerald-600);
  transition: width 0.3s ease;
}

.nav-link:hover {
  color: var(--color-emerald-700);
}

.nav-link:hover::after,
.nav-link.active::after {
  width: 100%;
}

/* Mobile Menu Hamburger Animation - Using Tailwind-compatible styles */
#mobile-menu-btn.active .hamburger-line:nth-child(1) {
  transform: rotate(-45deg) translate(-2px, 6px);
}

#mobile-menu-btn.active .hamburger-line:nth-child(2) {
  opacity: 0;
}

#mobile-menu-btn.active .hamburger-line:nth-child(3) {
  transform: rotate(45deg) translate(-2px, -6px);
}

}

    opacity: 1;

  background: linear-gradient(135deg, var(--color-emerald-700) 0%, var(--color-emerald-900) 100%);
  -webkit-background-clip: text;
  -webkit-text-fill-color: transparent;
  background-clip: text;
}

}

  box-shadow: var(--shadow-large);
}

  border-bottom: 1px solid transparent;

  vertical-align: top;
}

  border-radius: 50px;

  align-items: center;
  gap: 0.5rem;

}

  box-shadow: var(--shadow-medium);
  background: linear-gradient(135deg, var(--color-emerald-700) 0%, var(--color-emerald-800) 100%);
}

  padding: 1.5rem;
  margin: 1.5rem 0;
  border-radius: 0 8px 8px 0;
  position: relative;
}

  position: absolute;
  left: -4px;
  top: 0;
  bottom: 0;

}

}

  50% { opacity: 0.5; }
}
